newsitem.title: JAPAN: Next Thai govt could last 18 months -- deputy PM.
newsitem.headline: Next Thai govt could last 18 months -- deputy PM.

text.p: The government which wins power in Thailand's November 17 general election is likely to last about 18 months, visiting Thai Deputy Prime Minister Kasem S. Kasemsri said on Thursday.
"The next government probably has about a year and a half, a little more perhaps, but not more than that," Kasem told Reuters Financial Television in an interview.
Kasem said legislation for political reform had been passed and a constituent assembly would be held during the next government's time in power.
"Once the constitution has been approved, either by the house or by the people, then we expect to have another election," he said.

Foreign investors, who have shunned the Thai stock market, helping to push the bourse to three-year lows, would be lured back if Thailand has a stable government, Kasem said, adding that a government lasting 18 months would be considered a stable one.
Thailand has had five governments in as many years.
Kasem came to Japan to attend a seminar on Japan-U.S. security ties.

An independent, Kasem said he did not expect any one party to win a majority in the election, but added that the opposition Democrat Party, and the New Aspiration Party -- which is part of the ruling coalition, were expected to win the most seats.
Tackling Thailand's ballooning current account deficit would be the top economic goal of the new government, Kasem said.
He said Thailand's current account deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) was slightly high and the best remedy would be to cut public spending.
The Thai central bank has projected a current account deficit of 7.8 percent of GDP this year.
